Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Integrative Training in Motor Control and Movement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) project builds links broadly across Chicago's scientific community to develop an integrative training program for U.S. doctoral students in motor control and movement. To develop an integrative understanding of movement, it is necessary to address both the biology and the engineering of the systems involved and how they work together. Students from graduate programs at the University of Chicago and Northwestern University will obtain the biological and engineering backgrounds required to develop the integrative approach needed to take the field in new directions. Educational tools include a boot camp, a three-quarter common core curriculum, a discussion series, required laboratory rotations, and workshops and seminars at the Field Museum. The program will involve outreach to local Chicago-area schools, with training for students and faculty in the development and conduct of effective outreach. Mentoring of undergraduate students by IGERT graduate trainees will be done in close collaboration with local universities that primarily serve underrepresented minorities in the Chicago area. A trans-institutional website will highlight opportunities and results related to this program's IGERT goals and provide resources for teachers and students. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This IGERT program (MotoIGERT: Integrative training in motor control and movement) provided a multi-institution training community for graduate students. As a partnership of the University of Chicago, Northwestern University and The Field Museum, the students had access to faculty and facilities representing neuroscience, biomechanics, fluid and mechanical engineering, computational neuroscience, evolutionary biology and development. Through a course newly designed for this program, these fields were integrated to examine structure and function of organisms from multiple perspectives. This course complimented the disciplinary focus of other aspects of trainees’ curricula. By hosting courses and events at the Field Museum, trainees were introduced to museum research and education opportunities. Two students received Field Museum Womens’ Board Fellowships subsequent to their traineeships in the MotoIGERT program and continued their research at the museum.

 

The research efforts of MotoIGERT trainees have been productive and highly integrative. A number of trainees have worked across laboratories to integrate research approaches of faculty trainers in their projects, and many collaborative papers have been published as a result. Other trainees have moved between labs to perform several stand-alone projects and papers with disciplinary focus that complement each other in the trainee’s dissertation to demonstrate scientific breadth. IGERT trainees included experimental biologists, computational biologists and engineers. Interactions among trainees in the MotoIGERT program through courses, lab tours and social events were also important opportunities for developing greater appreciation of interdisciplinary opportunities and approaches. 

 

A significant component of the project was training in education and outreach. In its first year the MotoIGERT developed an education training program that included an intensive week-long summer bootcamp in scientific teaching, as well as in-school experiences through the academic year. Trainees receive an abbreviated version of the curriculum of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute/National Academies of Science Summer Institutes, covered in Handlesman et al.’s 2007 book Scientific Teaching. Some of the topics covered included: student-centered teaching, formative and summative assessment, communicating to diverse audiences, and honing their message.  Trainees practiced outreach skills by working directly with students from the Chicago Public Schools on the South Side of Chicago. Some opportunities were partnerships with after-school programs and in others the students worked directly with teachers in the classroom.

 

Through the six-year duration of the MotoIGERT program, it trained 26 graduate students. Of those, nine have received PhDs so far. Graduates took many directions after graduation, some into postdocs in research science, others in STEM careers, including research computing, research in K-12 STEM education, and science writing. One is a founder of a science and technology start-up company.

 

The IGERT provided an opportunity to develop the training program and evaluate and improve program elements. Six-years in, the program is continuing. The training program is well established and integrated with standing curricula. This made it possible to apply for another training grant, from a different agency, to increase the number of trainees in neuromechanics. That proposal was successful, the program started in fall of 2015 at the University of Chicago. The program will continue to encourage efforts that span areas of science and engineering.
